body: run `python -m ipykernel` to get kernel tracebacks, this may help to find out why.

Thanks for the suggestion, could you let me know if there is something else I need to do to enable tracebacks?
I ran python -m ipykernel --debug and in another console I started qtconsole to connect to this. I still get the crash every 3 seconds, but there is no tracebacks in my debug session, I just get lots of the message below, once per crash. However, if I connect using 

`python console --existing` I get no crash, and ipython works normally

so it's something related to the qtconsole?

I've been trying to debug this, and have been unable to use any config options. I created a `jupyter_qtconsole_config.py` in 
`C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\envs\fx_env\etc\jupyter\jupyter_qtconsole_config.py` and put the following there:

```
c.IPKernelApp.verbose_crash = True
c.KernelRestarter.restart_limit = 0
c.KernelRestarter.debug = True
c.KernelManager.autorestart = False

```
from `https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter_client/issues/94`
However, there is no crash report, and it tries to restart...
does `jupyter qtconsole` use a different config file or settings?

have narrowed it down to the exact problem (I think):
`ipython qtconsole --existing` should just use an existing kernel which I started with `ipython kernel` . I can connect to this kernel using `'ipython console --existing'`. qtconsole connects to this kernel fine too, but embedded in the console is the repeating message 'kernel died, restarting', please see the attached image. I can see from the jupyter/runtime directory that the only kernel is the one I started and is working from from the ipython console. I can confirm that this is every 3 seconds, and if I edit [client.py](https://github.com/jupyter/qtconsole/blob/efa3302d970e1a395ac9130f16a6e864bd3e593a/qtconsole/client.py#L26) to change the hardcoded 3 seconds there to 20 seconds, this message repeats every 20 seconds. Somehow, qtconsole thinks the kernel is dead. If I try to use the kernel from the ipython console, it is very slow to respond, and I get frequent 
`  warn('The kernel did not respond properly to an is_complete_request: %s.' % str(msg))`

I think this is similar to the issue:
https://github.com/jupyter/qtconsole/issues/319

Is there any way to debug this? It if helps, I am connecting via Citrix into a Windows 2008R2 server that is a multiuser box shared among several people simultaneously.

```
class QtHBChannel(SuperQObject, HBChannel):
    # A longer timeout than the base class
    time_to_dead = 3.0 #I changed this from 3.0 to 20.0 and I can see the message is once every 20 seconds

```
![qtconsole](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10646418/87380033-3021ba00-c5c4-11ea-8b0f-04c9d98bf25b.png)
Try to trash all your jupyter kernel specs. (see `jupyter kernelspec list`), the likely reason is you start a kernel from a different environment (?) That crashes.

I checked and the only kernel spec is in the conda env I created:

```
(fx_env) C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\envs>jupyter kernelspec list
Available kernels:
  python3    C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\envs\fx_env\share\jupyter\kernels\python3
```

I deleted that folder, and then just to be safe I ran `jupyter kernelspec list` again, but now it is showing:

```
(fx_env) C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\envs>jupyter kernelspec list
Available kernels:
  python3    C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\envs\fx_env\lib\site-packages\ipykernel\resources
```

Even if I delete this folder, this kernel does not go away. I have checked everywhere on this box, there is no other installation of python or anaconda, and this conda env is the only env that I created. The strange error is still there. i.e if I start a kernel, and connect to it using `ipython console --existing` and I do something like this, the print statement does nothing, If I press enter again, or run some otherline, the display shows, but with this error. Starting a qtconsole has the error as above.


At that point I do not know. Maybe it's some antivirus or firewall doing stuff. 

But honestly at that point that's where I would go modify the code and write
```
with open('~/log.log', 'a') as f:
    f.writeline(...)
```

Everywhere to figure out where things fail exactly, but I really don't see what could be happening.

I also get this same bug, except that it only happens during the kernel initialization time (when it is loading its startup code). I have only seen it in `qtconsole`, not other Jupyter frontends, such as the kernel gateway server.

```zsh
jupyter qtconsole --style solarized-light '--editor=/Users/evar/scripts//zshlang/wrappers//emacs_nowait.dash {filename}' '--stylesheet=' '--kernel=julia-1.6' '--gui-completion=ncurses' --debug
```
